description: This course examines the politics of international economic relations. The course will analyze the interplay between politics and economics in three broad areas: international trade, international finance, and economic development. In each section, we will first discuss economic theories that explain the causes and consequences of international commerce, capital flows, and economic growth. We will then explore how political interests, institutions, and ideas alter these predictions, examining both historical examples and current policy debates.
name: INTERNATIONAL POL. ECON

values.comments: This course examines the politics of international economic relations. Material covered during the semester includes analysis of the interplay between politics and economics in international trade, international finance, and economic development.  Students wrote that the course was “informative”. Additionally, some students commented that the readings were quite interesting, yet in some cases lengthy. Many students wrote that they found the class to be “useful” and one of the best they had taken at Penn.  Students praised Professor Pollack’s teaching style. Many said that he was the best professor that they have had at Penn. Students found his lectures to be “stimulating,” “valuable,” and “well-organized”. Additionally students wrote that Professor Pollack was able to communicate the material in a clear and engaging way.  This course is not listed as fulfilling any major college requirements. In addition, there are no prerequisites listed. The course is open to both college freshmen and upperclassmen. Many students wrote that they would recommend this class to majors and non-majors.
